topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Yuriy Timen’s background (Grammarly growth lead, now advisor) and previews a highly tactical episode on growing subscription products.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor reads for Flatfile (data onboarding/CSV import) and Modern Treasury (payments ops platform).

topics.title: Yuriy’s advising work and capacity
topics.summary: Yuriy and Lenny cover Yuriy’s Grammarly tenure, the types of companies he advises (e.g., Canva, Airtable, Hims, Otter, Flo), and how he structures his advising workload (3–3.5 days/week, ~4–5 companies max).

topics.title: Growth archetypes for subscription businesses
topics.summary: Yuriy outlines common growth “buckets” for subscription companies: paid growth when LTVs are strong, virality/referrals when network effects exist, and SEO when there’s a long-tail or programmatic opportunity (e.g., Canva templates).

topics.title: When virality and referrals actually work
topics.summary: They discuss signals for investing in virality: inherent product network effects (collaboration tools, marketplaces) versus “manufactured” virality, plus cases where strong brand love enables referrals even without network effects.

topics.title: SEO readiness: editorial, programmatic, data angles
topics.summary: Yuriy shares a practical framework for deciding whether to invest in SEO, emphasizing unique differentiation via editorial content, programmatic pages, or proprietary data, and recommends time-boxed experiments (e.g., 3 months).

topics.title: SEO execution: audits, specialists, and Graphite
topics.summary: They cover why SEO is specialized, why an external audit can be high leverage, and Yuriy recommends Ethan Smith/Graphite as a strong (higher-end) SEO resource.

topics.title: Paid growth shifts: payback windows and attribution
topics.summary: Yuriy explains how market conditions and iOS tracking changes are tightening acceptable payback windows (e.g., 12 months to ~6 months), increasing intolerance for un-attributed spend, and creating opportunities for disciplined advertisers as competition drops.

topics.title: Attribution tools: MMM and incrementality testing
topics.summary: They discuss the resurgence of Media Mix Modeling and the need for causal measurement via incrementality experiments, with tool mentions including Recast, Measured, and Incremental.

topics.title: Focus vs spreading thin across channels
topics.summary: Yuriy advises balancing focus with rapid iteration: avoid betting everything on one channel too early, but also avoid shallow tests across many channels that lead to false negatives (e.g., “we tried YouTube”).

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor read for Eppo, an experimentation/A-B testing platform for modern growth teams.

topics.title: Knowing when to stop: guardrails and judgment
topics.summary: Yuriy explains how to set objective test thresholds for some channels (impressions, creative angles, CTR benchmarks) while acknowledging other bets require judgment and periodic reevaluation rather than permanent abandonment.

topics.title: The 80/20 reality and diversification timing
topics.summary: They discuss how most companies rely heavily on one dominant growth engine (even at later stages), when to resist premature diversification, and when channel concentration becomes a serious risk (e.g., paid-heavy vs SEO-heavy dependence).

topics.title: Why “later-stage” tactics are moving earlier
topics.summary: Yuriy describes how the funding environment shifted priorities from growth-at-all-costs (favoring paid) to runway and sustainability, making longer-horizon investments like SEO more attractive earlier in a company’s lifecycle.

topics.title: Paid as learning vs paid as scalable engine
topics.summary: Yuriy distinguishes using paid for rapid messaging/positioning learnings versus using it as a profitable acquisition channel, and shares benchmark heuristics for prosumer funnels (site→signup and free→paid conversion).

topics.title: Onboarding as a major growth lever
topics.summary: Yuriy argues onboarding improvements are almost always high ROI for complex prosumer products, since guiding users to the right first experience prevents overwhelm and accelerates time-to-value.
